headline.main: Friendlier Skies on an Unfriendly Planet

docs.abstract: Article on various topics discussed at two-day annual conference of World Travel and Tourism Council, which was held in Qatar and drew about 1,000 representatives from travel industry and from world governments; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In Rome during the 1970's, I once stopped at a cafe where the proprietor kept a parrot on a perch by the bar. When the parrot abruptly uttered a sentence in Italian, I was utterly flabbergasted. I've always recalled that anecdote, with some embarrassment, as a sort of personal cultural watershed. Rube from Philadelphia that I was, it had simply never struck me until then that a parrot would speak anything but English.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: World Tourism Rises

docs.abstract: World Tourism Organization says tourism around world reached record in 2002; reports number of international arrivals reached 715 million, 3.1 percent rise from 2001 (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Tourism around the world reached a record last year despite fears of terrorism, although travelers stayed closer to home, made shorter visits and spent less, the World Tourism Organization said. For the first time, the number of international arrivals surpassed 700 million, reaching nearly 715 million, the organization said. That was a 3.1 percent rise from 2001, when the Sept. 11 attacks led to a decline of 0.6 percent from the previous year.
docs.snippet: Tourism around the world reached a record last year despite fears of terrorism, although travelers stayed closer to home, made shorter visits and spent less, the World Tourism Organization said. For the first time, the number of international arri...

headline.main: World Tourism Officials Look Hard for Optimism

docs.abstract: Delegates to World Tourism Organization meeting in Osaka, Japan, believe world tourism will continue to expand in long term despite terrorist attacks; Francesco Frangialli, organization's secretary general, says air security issues will be resolved, consumer confidence will return, and after bad fourth quarter of 2001, world tourism will resume growing by 4 percent per year; says some countries, like China, will probably gain, while others, like US, will probably lose; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Along with a tropical rain, gales of bad news battered a world tourism conference here this week: dozens of trans-Pacific flights canceled, hundreds of Japanese tour groups dropping trips to the United States and tourism bookings vanishing in Asia's poorest nations, including Cambodia, Nepal and Thailand. But inside the hall housing the World Tourism Organization meeting, industry veterans urged a steady hand at the tiller as the $500 billion travel and tourism industry navigates a world changed by the terror attacks of Sept. 11, when four commercial jets were hijacked in the United States and three were used as missiles.
docs.snippet: Along with a tropical rain, gales of bad news battered a world tourism conference here this week: dozens of trans-Pacific flights canceled, hundreds of Japanese tour groups dropping trips to the United States and tourism bookings vanishing in Asia...

headline.main: Learning the Art Of the Concierge

docs.abstract: Practical Traveler column on hotel concierge training course at nonprofit International School of Tourism in Fort Lauderdale, Fla; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT can be taught in a concierge school? To some degree, the teachers say, it is like a singing school: Techniques can be learned, but the talent -- in this case, the wish to be of service -- must be there to start. This became clear last month at the end of nine weeks of classes for new concierges offered by the nonprofit International School of Tourism in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., affiliated with the international concierge group, Les Clefs d'Or. As a student, Geoffrey Singleton of Myrtle Beach, S.C., was practicing for a job interview, a fellow student, Andressa Vasconcellos of Sao Paulo, Brazil, was questioning him from a prompt sheet. ''Why do you want this job?'' she asked. Without pause, Mr. Singleton answered, ''Because I was born to be a concierge; I just did not know what a concierge was.''
